newsitem.title: INDIA: BOMBAY SHARES TAKE A BEATING, INDEX SLUMPS 1.7 PCT.
newsitem.headline: BOMBAY SHARES TAKE A BEATING, INDEX SLUMPS 1.7 PCT.

text.p: Bombay blue chips closed sharply lower on Thursday battered by aggressive profit-taking by local institutions and speculators, traders said.
Shares turned tail in afternoon trade as a wave of selling orders struck, they said.
"It was unexpected. A lot of shakeout happened today," said Balaji Narayan, equities dealer at Prime Broking.
The strength of the reaction, which began late Wednesday, after uninterrupted advances toward all-time highs during the past few days was sudden and took a thin market by surprise, participants said.
"It appears that a lot of people who jumped on the buying bandwagon are getting out of the market," said Vetri Subramaniam, institutional sales dealer at SSKI Securities.
Foreign funds were mostly on the sidelines, dealers said.

Profit-taking began on Wednesday, curtailing a five-day old rally that pushed the blue chip index through the psychological 4,600 level at 4,605.41 -- just shy of its all-time high of 4,643.31 set on September 12, 1994.
The Bombay index surged nine percent in five consecutive days till Wednesday.
"A fall in prices will set the pace for a further jump. We should see some clarity tomorrow," said Ashith Kampani, head of dealing at JM Share & Stock Brokers.

Indian Finance Minister P. Chidambaram on Thursday denied a newspaper report that he was considering resigning, a spokeswoman said. She told Reuters the finance minister had called the report "false, baseless and mischievous".
The Business Standard newspaper said Chidambaram was considering the possibility of resigning after the government was forced to withdraw an insurance bill from parliament.
